Class RamachandranLibrary

  • java.lang.Object
    • RamachandranLibrary

  • public class RamachandranLibrary
extends java.lang.Object
    This singleton stores data on how (phi,psi) depends on the neighboring residue identity based on the Dunbrack data.

    Reference: Daniel Ting, Guoli Wang, Maxim Shapovalov, Rajib Mitra, Michael I. Jordan, Roland L. Dunbrack, Jr. Neighbor-dependent Ramachandran probability distributions of amino acids developed from a hierarchical Dirichlet process model. PLOS Comp. Biol. (April 2010).

    Use this command to check memory usage:

    jps | grep Rama | awk '{print $1}' | xargs jmap -histo:live | awk '{if ($1 == "Total" || NR < 20) {print}}'

      • getLeftDistribution

        public DiscreteProbabilityDistribution<SideChainRotamerLibrary.BackboneAngles> getLeftDistribution(AminoAcid leftAminoAcid,
                                                                                          AminoAcid centralAminoAcid)
        Returns a DiscreteProbabilityDistribution Pr(phi,psi | left AA - central AA). That is, given a sequence (left AA, central AA) in the N to C direction, gives the conditional probability that the central AA will have backbone angles (phi,psi).

        Parameters are not checked for correctness! For example, asking for the central amino acid to be AminoAcid.ALL will result in a NullPointerException. Probability distributions are generated on demand from internal lists of primitives to save memory.

        Parameters:
        leftAminoAcid - the amino acid on the left in the N to C direction
        centralAminoAcid - the amino acid on the right in the N to C direction
        Returns:
        the DiscreteProbabilityDistribution of (psi,phi) values of the central amino acid

      • getRightDistribution

        public DiscreteProbabilityDistribution<SideChainRotamerLibrary.BackboneAngles> getRightDistribution(AminoAcid centralAminoAcid,
                                                                                           AminoAcid rightAminoAcid)
        Returns a DiscreteProbabilityDistribution Pr(phi,psi | central AA - right AA). That is, given a sequence (central AA, right AA) in the N to C direction, gives the conditional probability that the central AA will have backbone angles (phi,psi).

        Parameters are not checked for correctness! For example, asking for the central amino acid to be AminoAcid.ALL will result in a NullPointerException. Probability distributions are generated on demand from internal lists of primitives to save memory.

        Parameters:
        centralAminoAcid - the amino acid on the left in the N to C direction
        rightAminoAcid - the amino acid on the right in the N to C direction
        Returns:
        the DiscreteProbabilityDistribution of (psi,phi) values of the central amino acid

      • getTripletDistribution

        public static DiscreteProbabilityDistribution<SideChainRotamerLibrary.BackboneAngles> getTripletDistribution(AminoAcid leftAminoAcid,
                                                                                             AminoAcid centralAminoAcid,
                                                                                             AminoAcid rightAminoAcid)
        Returns a DiscreteProbabilityDistribution Pr(phi,psi | left AA - central AA - right AA). That is, given a sequence (left AA, central AA, right AA) in the N to C direction, gives the conditional probability that the central AA will have backbone angles (phi,psi).

        This assumes all the amino acids are in the database. Don't use AminoAcid.ALL! This is not checked and will throw a NullPointerException.

        Algorithm, which is executed on demand:

        1. For all (psi,phi), calculate log Pr(phi,psi|C,L) + log Pr(phi,psi|C,R) - log Pr(phi,psi|C,R=ALL).

        2. Convert back to a regular probability.

        3. Create a DiscreteProbabilityDistribution, which will normalize the probabilities automatically.

        Pr(phi,psi|C,L) means the conditional probability that (phi,psi) will be observed given that the central amino acid is C and an amino acid L is to the left of it. The algorithm amounts to multiplying the independent probabilities that we get C,L and C,R, conditional on the central residue being C.

        Parameters:
        leftAminoAcid - the amino acid on the left on the left in the N to C direction
        centralAminoAcid - the amino acid in the middle in the N to C direction
        rightAminoAcid - the amino acid on the right in the N to C direction
        Returns:
        the DiscreteProbabilityDistribution of (psi,phi) values of the central amino acid

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For testing.
